October 18, 2009: Fiction
THE LOST SYMBOL, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $29.95.) Robert Langdon among
the Masons.
AN ECHO IN THE BONE, by Diana Gabaldon. (Delacorte, $30.) The descendants
of Jamie Fraser and his wife, Claire, search for clues about their flight from North
Carolina during the Revolution; the seventh Outlander novel.
ROUGH COUNTRY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $26.95.) Virgil Flowers
investigates a string of murders at a Minnesota resort for women.
THE LAST SONG, by Nicholas Sparks. (Grand Central, $24.99.) A 17-year-old girl
spends the summer with her divorced father in North Carolina and finds many kinds
of love.
THE HELP, by Kathryn Stockett. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam, $24.95.) A young white
woman and two black maids in 1960s Mississippi.
HER FEARFUL SYMMETRY, by Audrey Niffenegger. (Scribner, $26.99.) A woman
haunts the flat she’s left to her twin nieces near Highgate Cemetery in London.
THE PERFECT CHRISTMAS, by Debbie Macomber. (Mira, $16.95.) A 33-year-old
woman consults a matchmaker.
SOUTH OF BROAD, by Pat Conroy. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $29.95.) An
unlikely group’s friendship from the ’60s to the ’80s, by the author of "The Prince of
Tides."
ALEX CROSS’S TRIAL, by James Patterson and Richard DiLallo. (Little, Brown,
$27.99.) The detective Alex Cross writes a novel about his great-uncle, who fought
the Klan.
HOTHOUSE ORCHID, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam, $25.95.) A C.I.A. special agent
finds that much has changed, and not for the better, when she returns to her
Florida hometown.
JULIET, NAKED, by Nick Hornby. (Riverhead, $25.95.) A woman looking for a
change begins a relationship with a reclusive singer-songwriter about to release a
new album.
FROSTBITTEN, by Kelley Armstrong. (Bantam, $26.) The world’s only female
werewolf and her mate track a rogue who’s hunting humans in the Alaskan forest.
DEAD AND GONE, by Charlaine Harris. (Ace, $25.95.) Sookie Stackhouse
searches for the killer of a werepanther.
SPARTAN GOLD, by Clive Cussler with Grant Blackwood. (Putnam, $26.96.)
Husband-and-wife treasure hunters search for bottles of wine from Napoleon’s “lost
October 18, 2009
Non-Fiction
HAVE A LITTLE FAITH, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $23.99.) A suburban rabbi
and a Detroit pastor teach lessons about the comfort of belief.
ARGUING WITH IDIOTS, written and edited by Glenn Beck, Kevin Balfe and
others. (Mercury Radio Arts/Threshold Editions, $29.99.) The case against big
government.
TRUE COMPASS, by Edward M. Kennedy. (Twelve, $35.) The late senator’s
autobiography.
THE TIME OF MY LIFE, by Patrick Swayze and Lisa Niemi. (Atria, $26.) A memoir
by the actor, who died in September, and his wife.
THE MURDER OF KING TUT, by James Patterson and Martin Dugard. (Little,
Brown, $26.99.) Investigating the Boy King’s sudden death.
HIGH ON ARRIVAL, by Mackenzie Phillips with Hilary Liftin. (Simon Spotlight
Entertainment, $25.99.) The actress and daughter of Papa John Phillips recalls a
life of parties, drugs and a complicated relationship with her father.
WHERE MEN WIN GLORY, by Jon Krakauer. (Doubleday, $27.95.) The story of
Pat Tillman, the N.F.L. player who enlisted after 9/11, and the Army’s cover-up of
his death by friendly fire in Afghanistan.
THE GREATEST SHOW ON EARTH, by Richard Dawkins. (Free Press, $30.)
Evidence for evolution; a counterattack on advocates of intelligent design.
OUTLIERS, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Why some people
succeed, from the author of “Blink.”
OFFICIAL BOOK CLUB SELECTION, by Kathy Griffin. (Ballantine, $25.) A
humorous memoir from the star of “My Life on the D-List.”
AMERICAN ON PURPOSE, by Craig Ferguson. (Harper/HarperCollins, $25.99.)
The Scottish-born comedian describes his journey to television stardom and
American citizenship.
END THE FED, by Ron Paul. (Grand Central, $21.99.) Abolishing the Federal
Reserve, by the Texas congressman.
HALF THE SKY, by Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn. (Knopf, $27.95.)
Women fighting sexual oppression in Asia and Africa.
CULTURE OF CORRUPTION, by Michelle Malkin. (Regnery, $27.95.) President
Obama and his team of tax cheats, petty crooks, influence peddlers and Wall
Street cronies.
